page.title: 09N.RONLDSAY SHEEP POUND
page.content: N.RONALDSAY SHEEP POUNDS All around the island, dry-stone sheep pounds have been built to collect in the sheep. There are ten of these en- closures still in use. At high-tide the sheep are rounded up by the men. Each owner recognises his own flock by the ear-markings which are cuts made into the ears. The sheep are gathered in for shearing, dipping, worming and for killing. Their flesh has a stronger taste because they eat seaweed on the shore. They usually stick to tangle or lamanaria. They also keep to their own area of the shore which is called a clo-jung.
